<description type="note">Title: The appearance on the way to Emmaus.
Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
<description type="note">Square brackets indicate sections of text unclear in the original and supplied by the current editor.</description>
[The Appearence on the way to Emmaus]

hic incipit aparicio cleophe et luce. Cleophas My brothir lucas I ?ow pray plesynge to ?ow if Ã¾at it be To Ã¾e castel of Emawus A lytyl way Ãat ?e vowche-saf to go with me. lucas All redy brother I walke with the to ?one castell with ryght good chere Euyn to-gedyr Anon go we brother cleophas we to infere. Cleophas A brother lucas I am sore mevyd Whan cryst oure mayster comyth in my mynde whan that I thynke how he was grevyd Joye in myn herte kan I non fynde he was so lowlye so good so kynde holy of lyf and meke of mood Alas Ã¾e jewys Ã¾ei were to blynde hym for to kylle Ã¾at was so good. lucas Brothyr cleophas ?e sey ful soth they were to cursyd and to cruell And judas Ã¾at traytour he was to loth Ffor gold and sylvyr his Mayster to selle the jewys were redy hym for to qwelle With skorgys bete out all his blood Alas Ã¾ei were to fers and ffelle Shamfully Ã¾ei henge hym on a rood. Cleophas ?a be-twen to Thevys Alas for shame they henge hym up with body rent Alas alas they were to blame to cursyd and cruel was Ã¾er intent Whan for thurste he was nere shent Ey?il and galle Ã¾ei ?ovyn hym to drynke Alas for ruthe his deth thei bent in a ffowle place of horryble stynke. lucas ?a And cawse in hym cowde they non fynde Alas for sorwe what was here thought And he dede helpe bothe lame and blynde And all seke men Ã¾at were hym browght A-?ens vice Alwey he wrought synfull dede wold he nevyr do ?it hym to kylle Ã¾ei sparyd nought Alas Alas why dede they so. Jhesus Well ovyr-take ?e serys in same to walke in felachep with ?ow I pray. lucas welcom serys in goddys name of good felachep we sey not nay. Jhesus Qwat is ?our langage to me ?e say that ?e haue to-gedyr ?e to sory and Evysum ?e ben Alway ?our myrthe is gon why is it so. Cleophas Sere me thynkyth Ã¾ou art a pore pylgrym here walkynge be Ã¾i selfe A-lone and in Ã¾e cete of jerusalem Ã¾ou knowyst ryght lytyl what Ã¾er is done Ffor pylgrymys comyn and gon ryth sone Ryght lytyl whyle pylgrymes do dwelle In all jerusalem as Ã¾ou hast gone I trowe no tydyngys Ã¾at Ã¾ou canst telle. Jhesus Why in Jerusalem what thynge is wrought What tydyngys fro thens brynge ?e. lucas A ther haue they slayn a man for nought gyltles he was as we telle the An holy prophete with god was he myghtyly in wurde and eke in dede of god he had ryght grett pooste Amonge Ã¾e pepyl his name gan sprede. he hyght jhesu of nazareth A man he was of ryght grett fame the jewys hym kylde with cruel deth. with-out trespas or Any blame hym to scorne they had grett game And naylid hym streyte on tyll a tre Alas Alas me thynkyth grett shame With-out cawse Ã¾at this xulde be. Cleophas ?a sere and ryght grett trost in hym we had All Israel countre Ã¾at he xulde saue the thrydde day is this Ã¾at he was clad in coold cley and leyd in grave ?itt woundyrful tydyngys of hym we haue Of women Ã¾at sought hym be-forn day lyth wethyr they sey truthe or ellys do raue We can not telle Ã¾e trew verdyth. Whan cryst in grave Ã¾ei cowde not se they comyn to us And Evyn thus tolde How Ã¾at An Aungell seyd to them thre that he xuld leve with brest fful bolde ?itt petyr and johan preve this wolde to Crystys graue they ran thei tweyne and whan they come to Ã¾e graue so coolde They fownde Ã¾e women fful trewe sertayne. Jhesus A ?e Ffonnys And Slought of herte Ffor to be-leve in holy scrypture haue not prophetys with wurdys smerte Spoke be tokenys in signifure That Cryste xuld deye ffor ?our valure And syth entre his joye and blys why be ?e of herte so dure And trust not in god Ã¾at myghtful is. Bothe Moyses and Aaron and othyr mo in holy scrypture ?e may rede it of Crystis deth thei spak Also And how he xuld ryse out of his pitt Owt of ffeyth than why do ?e fflitte Whan holy prophetys ?ow teche so pleyne turne ?oure thought and chaunge ?our witte And truste wele Ã¾at cryst doth leve a-geyne. lucas Leve Ageyn man be in pes how xulde A ded man evyr A-ryse I cowncell Ã¾e such wurdys to ses Ffor dowte of pylat Ã¾at hy? justyce he was slayn At Ã¾e gre A-syse be cowncell of lordys many on Of suche langage take bettyr A-vise In every company Ã¾er Ã¾ou dost gon. Christus Trewth dyd nevyr his maystyr shame Why xulde I ses than trewth to say Be Jonas Ã¾e prophete I preve Ã¾e same Ãat was in a Whallys body iij nyghtis and iij day So longe Cryst in his grave lay As Jonas was with-inne Ã¾e se his grave is brokyn Ã¾at was of clay to lyff Resyn A?en now is he. Cleophas Sey nott so man it may not be thow thyn exaunple be sumdele good Ffor jonas on lyve evyr more was he And Cryst was slayn vpon A rood The Jewys on hym they were so wood Ãat to his herte A spere they pyght he bled owt All his herte blood how xulde he thanne ryse with myght. Christus Take hede at Aaron and his dede styk Which was ded of his nature And ?it he floryschyd with flowrys ful thyk and bare Almaundys of grett valure The dede styk was signifure how cryst Ã¾at shamfully was deed and slayn As Ã¾at dede styk bare frute ful pure So cryst xuld ryse to lyve a-geyn. lucas That A deed styk ffrute xulde bere I merveyle sore Ã¾er of i-wys but ?itt hym sylf ffro deth to rere And leve A-geyn more woundyr it is That he doth leve I trost not this Ffor he hath bled his blood so red but ?itt of myrthe evyr moor I mys Whan I haue mende Ã¾at he is ded. Christus Why be ?e so hard of truste dede not Cryst reyse thorwe his owyn myght lazare Ã¾at deed lay vndyr Ã¾e duste And stynkyd ryght foule as I ?ow plyght To lyff Cryst reysid hym a-?en ful ryght out of his graue Ã¾is is serteyn why may nat Cryste hym self Ã¾us qwyght and ryse from deth to lyve Ageyn. Cleophas Now trewly sere ?our wurdys ben good I haue in ?ow ryght grett delyght I pray ?ow sere with mylde mood to dwelle with vs all Ã¾is nyght. Christus I must gon hens a-non ful ryght Ffor grett massagys I haue to do I wolde abyde yf Ã¾at I myght but at Ã¾is tyme I must hens go. lucas ?e xal not gon fro us Ã¾is nyght It waxit all derke gon is Ã¾e day Ã¾e sonne is downe lorn is Ã¾e lyght ?e xal not gon from vs A-way. Christus I may not dwelle As I ?ow say I must Ã¾is nyght go to my ffrende Ã¾erfore good bretheryn I ?ow pray lett me not my wey to wende. Cleophas Trewly from vs ?e xal not go ?e xal abyde with us here stylle ?our goodly dalyaunce plesyth us so We may nevyr haue of ?ow oure fylle We pray ?ow sere with herty wylle All nyght with us abyde And dwelle more goodly langage to talkyn vs tylle and of ?our good dalyaunce more ffor to telle. lucas ?a brothyr cleophas be myn Assent lete us hym kepe with strenth and myght Sett on ?oure hand with good entent And pulle hym with us Ã¾e wey well ryght The day is done sere and now it is nyght Why wole ?e hens now from us go ?e xal abyde as I ?ow plyght ?e xal not walke Ã¾is nyght vs ffro. Cleophas This nyght fro us ?e go not Away we xal ?ow kepe be-twen us tweyne to vs Ã¾erfore ?e sey not nay but walke with us Ã¾e wey is pleyne. Christus Sythyn ?e kepe me with myght and mayn With herty wyll I xal abyde. lucas of ?our abydyng we be fulfayn no man more wel-kom in Ã¾is werd wyde. Cleophas Off oure maystyr Cryst Jhesu Ffor ?e do speke so mech good I loue ?ow hertyly trust me trew he was bothe meke and mylde of mood Of hym to speke is to me food If ?e had knowe hym I dare wel say And in what plyght with hym it stood ?e wold haue thought on hym many A day. lucas Many A day ?a ?a i-wys he was a man of holy levynge Thow he had be Ã¾e childe of god in blys bothe wyse and woundyrfull was his werkynge But Aftere ?our labour and ferre walkynge takyth Ã¾is loff and etyth sum bred And than wyl we haue more talkynge Of Cryst oure maystyr Ã¾at is now ded. Christus Beth mery and glad with hert fful fre ffor of cryst jhesu Ã¾at was ?our ffrende ?e xal haue tydyngys of game and gle with-inne A whyle or ?e hens wende with myn hand Ã¾is bred I blys And breke it here as ?e do se I ?eve ?ow parte Also of Ã¾is this bred to ete and blythe to be. hic subito discedat christus ab oculis eorum. [Cleophas] A mercy god what was oure happe was not oure hert with loue brennynge Whan cryst oure mayster so nere oure lappe Dede sitte and speke such suete talkynge He is now quyk and man lyvenge Ã¾at fyrst was slayn and put in grave now may we chaunge all oure mornynge Ffor oure lord is resyn his seruauntys to saue. Lucas Alas for sorwe what hap was this Whan he dyd walke with vs in way he prevyd by scripture ryght wel i-wys Ã¾at he was resyn from vndyr clay We trustyd hym not but evyr seyd nay Alas for shame why seyd we so he is Resyn to lyve Ã¾is day out of his grave oure lord is go. Cleophas latt us here no lengere dwelle but to oure bretheryn Ã¾e wey we wende With talys trewe to them we telle that cryst doth leve oure mayster and frende. lucas I graunt Ã¾er-to with hert ful hende lete us go walke forthe in oure way I am ful joyfull in hert and mende Ã¾at oure lord levyth Ã¾at fyrst ded lay. Cleophas Now was it not goodly don of cryst jhesu oure mayster dere he hath with us a large wey gon And of his vprysyng he dede us lere Whan he walkyd with us in fere And we supposyd hym both dede and colde Ã¾at he was A-resyn ffrom vndyr bere be holy scripture Ã¾e trewth he tolde. lucas Ryght lovyngely don for-sothe this was What myght oure mayster tyl us do more Than us to chere Ã¾at fforth dede pas and ffor his deth we murnyd ful sore Ffor loue of hym oure myrthe was lore We were ffor hym ryght hevy in herte but now oure myrth he doth restore Ffor he is resyn bothe heyl and qwert. Cleophas That he is Ã¾us resyn I haue grett woundyr An hevy ston ovyr hym Ã¾er lay how shulde he breke Ã¾e ston A-soundyr Ã¾at was deed and colde in clay Euery man Ã¾is mervayle may And drede Ã¾at lord of mekyl myght but ?it of Ã¾is no man sey nay Ffor we haue seyn hym with opyn syght. lucas That he doth leve I woot wel this he is A-resyn with flesch and blood A levynge man for-sothe he is Ã¾at rewly was rent upon a rood All heyl dere brothyr and chaunge ?our mood Ffor cryst doth levyn and hath his hele We walkyd in wey with cryst so good and spak with hym wurdys fele. Cleophas Evyn tyll Emawus Ã¾e grett castell ffrom jerusalem with hym we went Syxti ffurlonge as we ?ow telle we went with hym evyn passent he spak with us with good entent Ã¾at Cryst xuld leve he tolde tyll us And previd it be scripture verament vade worlych nota worlych trust me trewe it is ryght thus. lucas ?a and whan he had longe spokyn vs tylle he wold ffrom vs agon his way with strenght and myght we keptyn hym stylle And bred we tokyn hym to etyn in fay he brak Ã¾e loff As Evyn on tway As ony sharpe knyff xuld kytt breed Ã¾er-by we knew Ã¾e trewth Ã¾at day Ã¾at cryst dede leve and was not deed. Petrus Now trewly serys I haue grett woundyr of these grete merveylis Ã¾at ?e vs telle In brekynge of bred fful evyn A-soundyr oure mayster ?e knew and lord ryght well ?e sey Cryst levith Ã¾at jewys dyd qwelle tyll us glad tydyngys Ã¾is is serteyn and Ã¾at oure mayster with ?ow so longe dede dwelle it doth well preve Ã¾at he levith a-geyn.
